f5af2b715248.name: The Startup
f5af2b715248.shortDescription: Handpicked business, marketing, design, and technology…

paragraphs.text: The only path then, to build a lasting tech company, lies in successfully making the jump from one S-curve to another.
paragraphs.name: f806
e6c5
paragraphs.text: Build a family of products instead of relying on just a single cash cow or star product. Facebook (with Messenger, Whatsapp, Instagram) is a great example. Building a family of products means you’ve hedged your bets with multiple products each at different stages of their curve.
The life cycle of technology products is almost embarrassingly predictable. It is best represented by an S-curve, based on decades of empirical evidence as seen in countless industries.
paragraphs.name: c093
9fc9
paragraphs.text: You’re never in the ‘sell-more-of-your-cash-cow’ business. You’re always in the ‘solve-particular-pain-point’ business.
Companies that don’t grasp these simple truths are now dying faster than ever. (The average life expectancy of a Fortune 500 company today is a mere 15 years vs 75 years back in 1960.)
paragraphs.name: 3bcb

paragraphs.text: Very interesting point. I suppose the other fallacy is not knowing when that s curve starts to peak, right? Nevertheless, as a writer, I sometimes wonder if that means the books I write are just another product or if some of them are in the realm of art (I know, I know, bear with me🙊).

virtuals.subtitle: And as far as art is concerned (especially in today’s world which seems more than willing to commodify it), what does the curve look like…

paragraphs.text: The graphs are yours?
I disagree with this example. Facebook did not in fact build these products. They bought competitors out of fear and have done little to integrate the products in meaningful ways in most cases.

paragraphs.name: 44df

paragraphs.text: As far as I know, he was the first to describe the technology adoption life-cycle. Crossing the Chasm was about getting from "early adopters" to "early majority," a point at which most start-ups fail.

paragraphs.text: Nicely done, Abhishek. Another aspect of the innovator’s dilemma is related to Theodore Levitt’s Marketing Myopia ie knowing what business you’re in. Blackberry got hit by two tidal waves at once: ubiquitous availability (mobile) and the consumerization of IT.
